William F. May Professor and Director
Institute of Optics, University of Rochester

William F. May Professor and Director (i.e., dept. chair) of The Institute of Optics, a prominent academic department at the University of Rochester.  A member of the Rochester faculty since 1980, he served as Director of The Institute of Optics during 1993-2000.  He is a Fellow of the Optical Society of America (OSA), the American Physical Society (APS), the American Association for the Advancement of Science (AAAS), and the International Society for Optical Engineering (SPIE).  He is a former (elected) member of OSA’s Board of Directors and served as a Topical Editor of the Journal of the Optical Society of America from 1994-1997.  Prof. Hall is the recipient of two undergraduate teaching awards at Rochester, is the author of more than 125 refereed journal articles and several book chapters, and is the editor of the 1993 reprint volume Coupled-Mode Theory in Guided-Wave Optics (SPIE Press).  He has supervised to completion twenty-one Ph.D. dissertations and six M.S. theses.

Education: University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

In 1980 I took a leave of absence from a secure, tenured position as professor of physics and chair of the Department of Mathematics and Physics at Newberry College to spend just one year learning about computer science at the University of North Carolina. There, in Chapel Hill, I met two people who changed my life: Professor Steve Pizer of the UNC department of computer science, who introduced me to the field of medical imaging, and Dr. Patricia Robinson, a resident in Pediatrics, with whom I fell in love. I gave up my position at Newberry in 1981 to embark on a new career in medical image processing. In 1982 Vanderbilt University hired me as assistant professor of computer science. Pat and I have lived happily ever after in Nashville, Tennessee. In 2010, I retired from teaching to focus on research.

Experience: I am currently a Professor of Computer Science and Engineering in the Department of Electrical Engineering and Computer Science, and also a Senior Research Scientist in the Institute for Software Integrated Systems at Vanderbilt University. I got tenured and promoted to Associate Professor starting Sept 2010, and to full professor starting July 2018. My primary area of research brings together model-based software development and Middleware for which we have coined the phrase "Model-driven Middleware". I focus on solving timeliness, reliability and security problems for distributed, real-time and embedded systems. Most recently my work focuses on distributed systems problems in cloud/fog and edge computing.
I worked in Bell Labs for 3.5 years before joining Vanderbilt University. I was involved with the standardization of Fault Tolerance CORBA. I also worked on some internal projects.

My research advisor was Prof. Douglas C. Schmidt. I worked on devising the technology for real-time and high-performance CORBA object request brokers. I also got a chance to learn a great deal on design patterns, etc from Doug.

My stay at WashU also gave me a chance to interact with experts in the field of Computer Networks including Prof. Jon Turner, Prof. George Varghese, and Prof. Guru Parulkar.  In the realm of compiler technology, I had a chance to work with Prof. Ron Cytron.

In addition to being a graduate student, I was also involved as a part time programmer at the Electronic Radiology Lab, where I worked with Prof. G. James Blaine and Steve Moore on the DICOM protocol implementation.

I worked with my advisor Dr. Arunabha Sen towards my Master's thesis on Semi-Automated Test-suite Generation for Protocol Testing. In particular, I focused on using the Estelle language for protocol specification. I modified an algorithm that used the Unique Input-Output sequences for my thesis.

Professor Ndukaife heads the Laboratory for Innovation in Optofluidics and Nanophotonics (LION) at Vanderbilt, where he and his team conduct research projects on optically-resonant nanostructures for confining and manipulating light at the deeply sub-wavelength scale. Prof. Ndukaife and his team are developing nano-optical tweezers capable of stable trapping of nanometer-scale objects. The conventional optical tweezer technology, which was recently recognized with a 2018 Physics Nobel prize can readily trap microscopic objects but faces challenges with the trapping of nanoscale objects due to the diffraction limit. The nano-optical tweezers being developed by Prof. Ndukaife and his team aims to solve these challenges and enable new applications not previously possible.
The projects are funded by the US National Science Foundation and Vanderbilt University.
Nanofabrication of nanophotonic structures, conducting plasmonic trapping experiments, numerical simulations of coupled electromagnetic, heat transfer and fluid dynamics problems

Vanderbilt University - Radiation Effects and Reliability Group
Education: Layout-Aware Modeling and Analysis Methodologies for Transient Radiation Effects on Integrated Circuit Electronics

The design of radiation-hardened ICs is increasingly simulation driven, and increased costs to fabricate designs require engineers to consider transient radiation effects in the simulation and design phase to limit fabrication and test. This work advances the historical modeling approaches with bias-dependent and layout-aware methods for modeling the dose-rate and single-event effects in advanced technologies. A novel layout-aware analysis method is developed, utilizing a hybrid of compact models (for efficiency) and spatially-aware layout objects (for geometric charge collection accuracy), in an industry standard integrated circuit design tool flow. The methods developed in this research are being actively utilized in radiation-effects research at universities, aerospace and defense corporations, and commercial integrated circuit design and manufacturing facilities.
Masters Thesis Title: The Design of a Custom Single-Event Hardened Analog-to-Digital Converter

Experience: Dean of the School of Engineering

Fauchet has overseen the construction of Vanderbilt’s first research building in more than a decade, the Engineering and Science Building that opened in August 2016. The ESB is designed to foster interdisciplinary research, collaboration, and innovation. As a thought leader Dean Fauchet introduced the concept of "intellectual neighborhoods" that highlights the School of Engineering’s interdisciplinary research competencies instead of traditional departmental lines. As a successful entrepreneur, he has refocused the research and education missions among faculty and students toward entrepreneurship and innovation by creating makerspaces, outfitting design labs, and encouraging design throughout the curriculum. He also holds numerous patents and founded a successful start-up company.

CompSustNet: Expanding the Horizons of Computational Sustainability

CompSustNet (http://www.compsust.net), a vast research network powered by the nation's recognized university computer science programs, charged with applying the emerging field of computational sustainability to solving the world's seemingly unsolvable resource problems. Put simply, the project will enlist some of the top talents in computing, social science, conservation, physics, materials science, and engineering to unlock sustainable solutions that safeguard our planet's future.
